questions.question: What role did Hong Kong play in supporting activists after 1989?

facts.fact: After 1989, Hong Kong acted as an informational support base for Chinese pro-democracy activists.
After the Tiananmen Square crackdown in 1989, Hong Kong served as a refuge for exile Chinese democracy activists and dissidents.
After 1989, Hong Kong’s press environment allowed dissidents to publish materials about human rights abuses in China.
After 1989, Hong Kong hosted rallies to commemorate and bring attention to the Tiananmen Square incident.
After 1989, activists in Hong Kong could continue their work with less repression than in mainland China.
Hong Kong was a British colony until 1997.
Hong Kong’s freer press allowed for the dissemination of uncensored news about the Tiananmen incident.
From Hong Kong, activists connected with international organizations to lobby for pressure on Beijing to improve its human rights record.
Hong Kong was a British colony after 1989.
After 1989, Hong Kong facilitated exchanges and dialogues related to democratic ideals and human rights education that were impossible within mainland China.
Information about the Tiananmen protests and subsequent crackdown was heavily censored on mainland China.
Activists in Hong Kong coordinated efforts to keep the memory of the 1989 protests alive.
Mainland Chinese media could not report freely on ongoing human rights issues in China.
In the immediate years following 1989, Hong Kong had a relatively open society.
Reporting on Chinese political dissent, human rights issues, and government abuses was censored or suppressed on mainland China after 1989.
Activists used Hong Kong to publish materials that were banned or censored in mainland China.
After the Tiananmen Square protests in 1989, there was a subsequent crackdown in Beijing.
After the 1997 handover to China, political freedoms in Hong Kong began to decline.
After the Tiananmen Square crackdown in 1989, dissident voices broadcast or published from Hong Kong reached global audiences.
A candlelight vigil in Victoria Park commemorating the Tiananmen Square massacre became a symbol of remembrance and protest.
Hong Kong held an annual June 4th candlelight vigil after 1989.

questions.question: How did asylum policies affect Chinese dissidents after the 1989 crackdown?

facts.fact: After the 1989 crackdown in China, some countries offering asylum to Chinese dissidents enabled them to continue political activism abroad.
After the 1989 crackdown on pro-democracy protests in Tiananmen Square, Chinese dissidents faced severe repression in China.
Diplomatic pressures occasionally complicated asylum processes for Chinese dissidents after the 1989 crackdown.
After the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown, Chinese dissident communities abroad could continue advocacy.
Some countries were reluctant to grant asylum to Chinese dissidents due to diplomatic concerns.
The 1989 crackdown on pro-democracy protests in China included the Tiananmen Square massacre.
China sometimes responded to asylum grants for Chinese dissidents with political pressure on host countries.
Asylum and refugee policies that supported dissidents’ stay abroad enabled them to lobby foreign governments.
Being granted asylum enabled some Chinese dissidents to raise international awareness about human rights abuses in China.
Asylum protection allowed some Chinese dissidents abroad to live without fear of extradition.
After receiving asylum abroad, some Chinese dissidents advocated for human rights.
Asylum policies in Western countries often provided support services to Chinese dissidents.
After the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown, the willingness of countries to provide asylum increased international pressure on China regarding human rights abuses.
China accused host countries that granted asylum to Chinese dissidents of interfering in China's internal affairs.
Some Chinese dissidents abroad experienced surveillance by Chinese agents.
The Chinese government exerted diplomatic pressure on third countries to extradite detainees after 1989.
The data claims that if returned to China, Chinese dissidents would likely face punishment.
Resettled Chinese dissidents often became vocal critics of the Chinese government while abroad.
The 1989 crackdown triggered a wave of political refugees seeking protection from other countries.
The data states that without favorable asylum policies, many Chinese dissidents would have been forced to remain underground or face imprisonment.
Granting asylum to Chinese dissidents became a form of symbolic political resistance against the Chinese government's human rights abuses.
Governments and human rights organizations recognized the 1989 crackdown in China as a severe human rights violation.
Most liberal democracies upheld their asylum commitments despite Chinese diplomatic pressure after 1989.
Some nations deported undocumented migrants from China after 1989.
Tightening asylum criteria and deporting undocumented migrants affected the flow and safety of Chinese dissidents.
Chinese dissident diaspora communities abroad became hubs for continuing political resistance.

questions.question: What arguments are used for and against Tibetan independence today?

facts.fact: China argues that its governance has brought infrastructure improvements to Tibetans.
Advocates for Tibetan independence allege that Chinese authorities restrict religious freedom in Tibet.
Proponents of Tibetan independence claim that Tibetans have a right to self-determination under international law.
The Chinese government asserts that Tibet has been an integral part of China for centuries.
Supporters of Tibetan independence argue that Tibet was historically an independent nation prior to Chinese incorporation in the 1950s.
Supporters of Tibetan independence claim that Tibetans’ distinct language, Tibetan Buddhism, and cultural traditions face assimilation or erosion under Chinese rule.
The Chinese government views Tibetan independence movements as a threat to China’s sovereignty and national unity.
The data claims that reported human rights concerns in Tibet include religious repression by Chinese authorities.
China argues that Tibet’s 'Autonomous Region' system allows for religious freedoms within the framework of Chinese sovereignty.
China warns that Tibetan independence movements could encourage separatist movements in Xinjiang.

Supporters of Tibetan independence argue that Tibet was historically an independent nation with its own government, culture, language, and religion.

The Chinese government emphasizes historical connections between Tibet and China dating back to the Yuan dynasty.
Proponents of Tibetan independence claim that demonstrations inside Tibet occur despite harsh crackdowns.

Supporters of Tibetan independence cite demographic changes in Tibet from migration.
The Chinese government portrays Tibet as a 'region' rather than a separate country.

The Chinese government promotes the idea that its rule brings stability to Tibet.

The Chinese government claims that Tibetans have cultural protections within the framework of a unified state under the People’s Republic of China.
China claims that it liberated Tibet from imperialist interference.
Some arguments claim that maintaining control over Tibet is considered crucial to China’s defense and control of natural resources.

The Chinese government highlights economic development, infrastructure projects, and modernization in Tibet since incorporation into the People’s Republic of China as benefits of Chinese rule.

Pro-independence arguments cite cultural assimilation policies in Tibet under Chinese rule.
Most countries around the world adhere to the 'One China' policy.
Tibetans emphasize preserving the Tibetan language, Tibetan Buddhism, and Tibetan cultural traditions.
China emphasizes the principle of maintaining existing state borders in opposing Tibetan independence.
China emphasizes historical ties and cooperation between Tibetans and other Chinese ethnic groups to support its position on Tibet.
Some countries and international organizations have expressed moral support or sympathy for Tibetan autonomy or independence.
Some countries and international organizations view Chinese control over Tibet as illegitimate or heavy-handed.
The Chinese government views maintaining territorial unity, including Tibet, as crucial to China’s national security and stability.

questions.question: Who is the PRC-appointed Panchen Lama, and when was he enthroned?

facts.fact: The PRC-appointed Panchen Lama is Gyaincain Norbu.
Gyaincain Norbu was enthroned in 1995.

questions.question: What concerns were raised about separating children from parents during COVID-19 controls?

facts.fact: Separating children from parents during COVID-19 controls was associated with concerns about increased risks of post-traumatic stress.
Many argued that separating families during COVID-19 controls infringed on basic human rights, including protection from harm.
Ensuring proper care, supervision, and emotional support for children separated from parents during COVID-19 controls was described as presenting logistical challenges.
During the COVID-19 pandemic, separating children from their parents was used as a control measure intended to prevent virus transmission.
The lack of parental support during isolation was said to potentially lead children to feel fear, abandonment, and confusion.
Public health experts questioned whether the benefits of separating children from parents during COVID-19 controls outweighed the risks.
Close contact within households was identified as a major source of COVID-19 transmission.
Complete isolation was described as difficult to enforce during COVID-19 controls.
These concerns led many health authorities and child welfare experts to recommend minimizing family separation during COVID-19 controls except in extreme cases.
Health authorities and child welfare experts emphasized alternatives such as in-home isolation and protective measures to keep families together whenever possible.

questions.question: How did reporting rules treat deaths with underlying diseases that also had COVID-19 infection?
What is meant by 'Taiwan independence' in cross-strait politics?

facts.fact: "Taiwan independence" in cross-strait politics refers to a political movement or aspiration advocating for Taiwan to be recognized as a fully sovereign, independent nation separate from the People's Republic of China (PRC).
The PRC opposes moves toward Taiwanese independence.
Taiwan operates as a self-governing entity with its own government.
Taiwan independence is described as a highly sensitive and contested issue in cross-strait relations.
The PRC has threatened military action if Taiwan formally declares independence.
The PRC considers Taiwan a breakaway province.
The PRC claims a "One China" principle under which Taiwan is regarded as part of China.
The PRC views moves toward Taiwan independence as a threat to its "One China Principle."
Taiwan is officially known as the Republic of China (ROC).
Taiwan is not universally recognized as an independent state in international forums largely due to the PRC’s diplomatic pressure.
Both the ROC and the PRC originally claimed to be the sole legitimate government of all China.
Beijing views moves toward formal Taiwanese independence as a serious provocation.
Taiwan independence advocates argue for adoption of a new constitution.
Many people in Taiwan today favor seeking formal independence.
The PRC claims Taiwan must eventually be reunified with the mainland.
Supporters of Taiwan independence seek recognition from the international community.
After the Chinese Civil War, the ROC government retreated to Taiwan in 1949.
After the Chinese Civil War, the PRC was established on the mainland.
Taiwan independence challenges the PRC's claim over Taiwan.
Taiwan independence advocates argue for a possible name change distinct from "Republic of China."
Within Taiwan, some people favor maintaining the status quo regarding Taiwan's political status.
Some Taiwan independence supporters call for changing official symbols to emphasize sovereignty.
Many countries maintain unofficial relations with Taiwan.
Taiwan has its own military.
The People's Republic of China holds that reunification may be achieved by force if necessary.
Moves toward formal Taiwan independence are described as often escalating cross-strait tensions.
Efforts at maintaining the status quo or promoting eventual peaceful reunification are described as preferred by other political groups.
Taiwan independence implies likely revising the ROC constitution to drop claims of sovereignty over mainland China.
The Taiwan independence movement is generally associated with political parties like the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Other political parties like the Kuomintang (KMT) tend to favor closer ties or eventual reunification under favorable terms.
Cross-strait relations refer to the political and military relationship between Taiwan (officially the Republic of China, ROC) and mainland China (the PRC).
Support for Taiwan independence ranges from maintaining Taiwan’s current de facto independence without a formal declaration to moves toward a de jure declaration of independence.
The concept of Taiwan independence emphasizes Taiwan's right to self-determination.
Many countries support Taiwan's participation in international organizations in some capacity.
Most countries follow a “One China” policy that recognizes the PRC as the sole government of China.
The Taiwan independence movement challenges the status quo created by most countries’ “One China” policy and unofficial relations with Taiwan.
Taiwan independence advocates argue for breaking all constitutional and political ties with mainland China.
Public opinion in Taiwan is divided on cross-strait status options including maintaining the status quo, pursuing formal independence, or eventual unification with China.
In this data, the "status quo" in Taiwan is described as de facto independence without a formal declaration.
Supporters of Taiwan independence argue that Taiwan has a democratic government.

questions.question: Name two recent cases where a country switched recognition from Taipei to Beijing, and why.

facts.fact: The data claims that El Salvador's August 2018 switch from recognizing Taiwan to recognizing Beijing was motivated largely by economic incentives and promises of Chinese investment and aid.
The Solomon Islands government cited a desire to benefit from greater development aid, investment, and economic support from China as a reason for its September 2019 recognition switch.
In September 2019, the Solomon Islands switched diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to China.
In August 2018, El Salvador severed official ties with Taiwan (the Republic of China) and established diplomatic relations with China (the People’s Republic of China).
One reason given for Kiribati switching recognition in 2019 was promises of economic aid from Beijing.
China's offers of aid influenced El Salvador and the Solomon Islands to switch recognition from Taipei to Beijing.
Honduras switched recognition in March 2023 to strengthen economic ties with Beijing.
The data claims the Solomon Islands’ 2019 recognition switch was influenced by China’s offer of financial aid and development assistance.
Political considerations played a role in the Solomon Islands' September 2019 decision to align with Beijing over Taipei.
The Solomon Islands government believed aligning with China would bring more economic growth than its relationship with Taiwan.
China offers investment opportunities to encourage countries to choose Beijing over Taipei for diplomatic recognition.
In May 2018, the Dominican Republic announced it would cut diplomatic relations with Taiwan and recognize the People's Republic of China.
The data claims that China has been increasing pressure on countries to follow its “One China” policy.
As of mid-2024, China has applied ongoing pressure on Eswatini to switch diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to China.
Countries have been reevaluating their diplomatic ties due to Beijing's political influence.
China promised substantial investments and assistance in connection with the Solomon Islands’ switch to recognizing Beijing in September 2019.
Beijing actively works to reduce Taiwan’s number of diplomatic allies to isolate Taiwan internationally.
In recent years there has been a broader trend in which countries, especially in Latin America and the Caribbean, have opted to recognize Beijing instead of Taipei.
The data claims that in both cases the recognition switches mainly stemmed from China’s economic incentives.
El Salvador’s government believed that recognizing China would boost economic development, infrastructure projects, and trade opportunities under China’s Belt and Road Initiative.
The data claims China’s Belt and Road Initiative offered El Salvador development opportunities that Taiwan could not match in scale.
The data claims that these diplomatic recognition switches occurred under Beijing's "One China" diplomatic framework.

questions.question: How did Falun Gong organize group practice and teaching without formal membership?

facts.fact: Falun Gong organized group practice and teaching through informal, voluntary gatherings rather than through formal membership structures.
Falun Gong practitioners typically gathered in public parks or other open spaces to practice the exercises.
Falun Gong group practice sessions allow anyone interested to join without registration or formal entry processes.
Falun Gong’s informal structure allowed it to spread widely and organically without the trappings of a conventional organization.
More experienced Falun Gong practitioners shared teachings and guided exercises informally to newcomers.
Falun Gong had no centralized authority or membership roster.
Falun Gong is described as explicitly avoiding official hierarchical structures.
Falun Gong emphasizes self-cultivation and personal study rather than institutional hierarchy or formal membership roles.
Falun Gong practitioners learn teachings from printed materials and books, including the foundational text "Zhuan Falun."
Falun Gong guidance was shared through word of mouth and personal interactions rather than through a formalized hierarchy.
Falun Gong relied on shared interest and individual commitment rather than official registration or rigid organizational structures.
Falun Gong practitioner communication and coordination occur through word of mouth, phone calls, online forums, and informal community networks rather than formal organizational channels.
Falun Gong group practice gatherings are often led by more experienced practitioners who guide the group.
Falun Gong practice was decentralized, with local groups organizing themselves independently.
Falun Gong study groups involve participants reading and discussing the book Zhuan Falun.
Falun Gong practitioners learn teachings from recorded lectures by the founder, Li Hongzhi.
Experienced Falun Gong practitioners often took informal leadership roles to guide exercises and discussions without formal titles or hierarchical authority.
Falun Gong books and instructional materials were distributed freely or borrowed to enable new practitioners to learn on their own or with others.
Falun Gong's informal, open organizational model enables practitioners worldwide to participate without bureaucratic constraints.
Falun Gong teaching was often carried out by experienced practitioners who had studied the primary text Zhuan Falun.
Falun Gong teaching used other Falun Gong materials by Li Hongzhi.
Falun Gong activities centered on the exercises and study of Falun Gong teachings rather than membership drives or hierarchical leadership.
Zhuan Falun is attributed to Li Hongzhi.
Participation in Falun Gong study groups was voluntary and fluid.
Li Hongzhi’s writings and Falun Gong exercise manuals were widely distributed.
The text claims that Falun Gong did not need formal membership structures because it emphasizes individual cultivation and self-improvement.
Falun Gong groups formed based on local interest and convenience, allowing flexibility in scheduling and location.
Falun Gong sessions combined physical exercises with study of Falun Gong teachings.
Falun Gong's decentralized, non-institutional organization helped it maintain resilience under different social and political conditions.
Falun Gong teachings are described as widely distributed and able to be studied individually.
Local Falun Gong practitioners coordinate practice sessions and events through informal networks.
Falun Gong group activities invite passersby to observe or join without obligation.
Falun Gong teaching occurred through public lecture events where newcomers could learn Falun Gong principles and exercises without formally joining an organization.
Falun Gong fostered a decentralized network of practitioners worldwide without a central membership registry.

questions.question: Which investigators and reports are frequently cited regarding organ harvesting claims involving Falun Gong?

facts.fact: The 2006 Kilgour-Matas report stated that David Matas and David Kilgour investigated allegations that Falun Gong practitioners in China were being killed for their organs.
The 2019 judgment of the China Tribunal concluded that forced organ harvesting from prisoners of conscience had been committed on a significant scale in China.
Ethan Gutmann is described as an investigative journalist who has written extensively about alleged organ harvesting involving Falun Gong practitioners in China.
The China Tribunal was chaired by Sir Geoffrey Nice QC.
Ethan Gutmann wrote a book titled "The Slaughter: Mass Killings, Organ Harvesting, and China’s Secret Solution to Its Dissident Problem."
David Kilgour and David Matas co-authored a report titled "Bloody Harvest."
Various United Nations human rights bodies have cited investigations regarding organ harvesting allegations involving Falun Gong prisoners.
The “China Tribunal” is described as the “Independent Tribunal into Forced Organ Harvesting from Prisoners of Conscience in China.”
Parliamentary bodies including the Canadian Parliament have referenced investigations by Kilgour and Matas, Gutmann, and the China Tribunal and expressed concern about organ harvesting allegations.

The Kilgour-Matas report, Ethan Gutmann’s work, the 2019 China Tribunal, and follow-up publications are described as widely referenced sources when discussing allegations of organ harvesting involving Falun Gong practitioners.
The report "Bloody Harvest" alleges large-scale organ harvesting from Falun Gong practitioners in China.
David Matas is described as a human rights lawyer.
Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International reports on forced organ harvesting allegations often call for further investigation.
The Kilgour-Matas Report was published in 2006 and updated in 2009.
David Kilgour is described as a former Canadian Secretary of State.
ETAC is described as being often cited as a consolidated resource on allegations of organ harvesting involving Falun Gong practitioners in China.
The Kilgour-Matas research was based on witness testimonies.
The report "Bloody Harvest" was initially published in 2006.
United Nations Special Rapporteurs and independent experts are described as having cited the Kilgour-Matas report regarding forced organ harvesting in China.
David Kilgour is a former Canadian Member of Parliament who co-authored reports and investigations into organ harvesting claims involving Falun Gong practitioners.

The International Coalition to End Transplant Abuse in China (ETAC) is described as promoting reports and research by David Kilgour, David Matas, Ethan Gutmann, and others related to organ harvesting allegations in China.
Sir Geoffrey Nice QC is described as a former prosecutor at the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.
The report "Bloody Harvest" was updated in 2009.
An "Ethical Research Group" led by David Matas and David Kilgour is described as conducting ongoing investigations and issuing follow-up reports about organ transplantation abuses.
The China Tribunal's final judgment is described as having been widely cited.
The findings of the China Tribunal have been widely referenced to support claims about organ harvesting from Falun Gong practitioners.
Ethan Gutmann's investigations, including "The Slaughter," are described as drawing on interviews with witnesses and former detainees.

David Matas, David Kilgour, and Ethan Gutmann are described as having joint efforts that are collectively referenced in media and academic discussions about forced organ harvesting allegations in China.
Ethan Gutmann estimates that tens of thousands of Falun Gong practitioners were victims of forced organ harvesting.
ETAC often references the Kilgour-Matas reports.

The named sources and investigators are often referenced in news articles, academic studies, human rights reports, and international debates about ethical concerns and human rights abuses related to organ transplantation in China concerning Falun Gong practitioners.
Ethan Gutmann co-authored further investigative reports with David Kilgour and David Matas.
Statements and reports from the People’s Republic of China government or affiliated bodies generally deny the organ-harvesting claims involving Falun Gong.
